newsitem.title: USA: Six drown trying to cross Mexico-U.S. border.
newsitem.headline: Six drown trying to cross Mexico-U.S. border.

text.p: Six Mexicans trying to cross the border illegally into the United States got trapped in an irrigation ditch during a violent rainstorm and drowned, officials said on Wednesday.

U.S. Border Patrol agents were looking for a seventh body, believed to be that of a child. One of the dead, a woman in her 20s or 30s, was found with a diaper bag, leading authorities to believe a child was involved in the crossing attempt on Tuesday night.

According to Rob Daniels, spokesman for the Border Patrol's Tucson sector, Mexican authorities told U.S. police on Tuesday that 13 immigrants tried unsuccessfully to cross into Douglas along a ditch that runs under an official border-crossing point and that six of them had returned to Mexico.

Meanwhile, city workers trying to clear debris from the ditch as a result of the storm early on Wednesday found the body of a man. Police searching the area found four more bodies about six hours later, including that of a woman.

"At that point the Border Patrol was asked to search the entire area and drainage system," said Daniels. They soon found the sixth body, also a man. All victims were in their 20s and 30s, Daniels said. One was identified as a 35-year-old man from Quinta Moralos, Mexico.
The area in southeast Arizona, which usually gets no more than 10 inches (25 cm) of rain a year, was soaked with three inches (7.5 cm) in a single hour on Tuesday night.

"It is believed they were swept away and drowned as a result of the sudden onslaught of running water," said Daniels. "It's not uncommon that when these storms come up these dry river beds suddenly become roaring rapids. Runoff has little or no place to go."
